Theory: There is no treadmill run with movie viewing that Patrick Swayzeâ€™s posture in Roadhouse cannot get you through.
@Hanigsberg My biggest attraction to people is that they are passionate about an issue or something bigger than themselves.

My colleague @MeganTregunno left this read in my office today and canâ€™t wait to read it. But I PRACTICED no and instead of reading right away I am saving for a time that works. I guess Iâ€™m also just simply practicing patience and better judgment. ðŸ˜‚ https://t.co/Vc1i8e57DG
Iâ€™m my own work in progress but my refocus on who and what matters, what I REALLY need and want to show up for, feels good. And freeing. *twirls away*
This also means saying no to myself, or â€œaspirational meâ€ for things that arenâ€™t really a priority. I donâ€™t like being told no, eapecially from me. ðŸ˜‚

Iâ€™m reading Joan Didionâ€™s essays in Slouching Toward Bethlehem. She speaks abt catering, overextending ourselves can be a matter of lack of self respect. I donâ€™t agree really, but being able to put yourself and needs first can be challenging. Itâ€™s been an exercise in saying no. https://t.co/jmH7Go7lqk
I am lucky and privileged enough to do this. And my community work gives back so much.

This year my theme is â€œmore of lessâ€. To focus more deeply on fewer priorities, deepen what I am doing. I love saying yes, being open to opportunity. Now, I know what and who I want around me, and need to rid myself of or limit my distractions or offer reciprocity in some way.

Years ago I was presenting, following a presentation from a more experienced, well-respected, dynamic leader at a womenâ€™s conference. Her talk was â€œSay yes to everythingâ€. Unknowingly, mine was about â€œLearn to say noâ€. We realized both can work at different times in life.
